Posts.Content: MoodyMoo wrote: I'm trying to determine how "common" it might be to have one diagnosis from a core needle biopsy, and then a different diagnosis from an excisional biopsy from the same site.  On May 2nd, I had 2 stereotactic biopsies, both due to suspicious microcalcifications.  Site B had no atypia or malignancy, but Site A had FEA and LCIS.  Recommendation was for an excisional biopsy on Site A.  A follow up MRI didn't identify any additonal areas of concern in either breast. On May 31st, I had an excisional biopsy on Site A.  They found two foci of ADH, with no mention of LCIS or FEA.  While I suppose it's possible that the CNB completely removed the LCIS, I just find that strange.  My BS didn't have a great answer for me as well.  She just confirmed that due to both diagnoses that I am considered high risk, even since I have none of the other familial high risk indicators. Have you all experienced anything similar?  I guess I've got of different things going on in that small space, and wasn't certain how normal that was...  TIA...MoodyMoo Dx: 5/9/12 - LCIS, ALH, & FEA; 6/11/12 - ADH (My alphabet soup...) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Conflicting Findings from CNB to Excisional Biopsy MoodyMoo BLinthedesert

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 09:21PM MoodyMoo wrote: All of my issues were on the right...I'd already had 2 mammos, and 2 biopsies.  When I had the consultation with the breast surgeon, I started off with "well, if I'm going under general anesthesia for an excisional biopsy, we better make darn sure there's nothing on the left that needs to be looked at as well".  She was totally in agreement, and the MRI of both breasts didn't show any additional areas that needed attention.  However, I had no lumps or other symptoms...just microcalcs.
Posts.Title: Anyone only had one side looked at and never the other? akc820608 oregongal

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2012 09:13PM MoodyMoo wrote: I had a similar outcome as Alligans...I had my surgery on May 31st, and I still get occasional twinges of pain, and are more "achey" than anything else, especially during my period.  In fact, I subconsciously use my upper arm sometimes to nudge my breast when it starts to ache.  However, it caught the attention of a coworker who was wondering what the heck I was doing!  If it feels like something more, definitely get it checked out!
Posts.Title: Pain after biopsy shannon13 awitkus246
